arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged into three series: Sound recordings related to Jester Hairston; Sound recordings unrelated to Jester Hairston; and Jester Hairston subject files and musical scores. Each series is arranged by record size, first 12-inch records and then 10-inch records, and organized alphabetically within each subsection. The 12-inch records in series 2 are roughly alphabetized. Foreign language records are located at the end of series 1 and 2.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The records in this collection were part of a larger donation that Jester Hairston had wanted to deposit at Tufts University in the 1990s. For various reasons only the records were eventually accepted as donation. These were likely his personal record collection, including records recorded by him, purchased by him, given to him, or sent to him for professional review.
The collection documentation folder indicates that collection materials arrived at Tufts sometime between March-July 1993. Rose Oliveira, 2016-04-22

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Material in this collection was transferred to the DCA with no documentation regarding original order and we have been unable to determine any existing arrangement as most records had already been taken out of original boxes. We therefore imposed a new order; records were housed based on the preservation needs. For more information,see the complete report and instructions for cataloging the Hairston records in the collection documentation file.

In April 2021 this finding aid was reviewed for offensive description by Collections Management Archivist Adrienne Pruitt. Terms pertaining to slavery were updated according to P. Gabrielle Foreman, et al. "Writing about Slavery/Teaching About Slavery: This Might Help" community-sourced document, accessed December 15, 2020, https://docs.google.com/document/d/1A4TEdDgYslX-hlKezLodMIM71My3KTN0zxRv0IQTOQs/mobilebasic. The word "Black" was capitalized when used to refer to an identity or race.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of phonograph records, interviews, correspondence, clippings, press releases, speeches, musical scores, photographs, and student records. The bulk of the collection consists of approximately 800 record albums on which Hairston either appeared, or which he collected. Genres represented include jazz, blues, choral, spoken word, contemporary Christian, gospel, orchestral, folk, classical, and world music, dating from 1910-1990. Hairston was well-known for his compositions of 'Negro' spirituals, many of which are represented in the collection. The content of some unlabeled recordings in this collection are unknown because the material is not accessible using conventional record playing equipment. Also included are biographical materials on Hairston and subject files and musical scores by other composers.

Approximately one third of the records in this collection are directly related to Hairston; he either appears as conductor, director, performer, composer or artist on the albums. Some of the records appear to be unique recordings of Hairston, possibly made during rehearsals and never formally produced. A large portion of these records document Hairston's role as guest conductor at high school and university choirs throughout the United States from the 1960s-1980s, as well as his role as an international ambassador of music. Also included are records inscribed to Hairston or bearing other markings that relate to him. Foreign language records include those in Spanish, Russian, Danish, German, French, Greek, Swedish, Finnish, and Portuguese. The rest of the collection is comprised of records that were part of Hairston's personal collection, but in whose he recording he played no role. This section includes many commercially available records from the 1970s and 1980s, as well as rare 78rpm recordings from 1910-1930. The content of some unlabeled recordings in this collection are unknown because the material is not accessible using conventional record playing equipment.

The Hairston subject files and musical scores compose the smallest part of the collection. It contains a small amount of biographical information included press releases, interviews, speeches and student records. Also included, are subject files and musical scores by other composers and collaborators with Hairston. This includes Salli Terri (1922-1996), a popular 1960s singer, arranger, recording artist, and composer. She was also a professor of music and director of a woman's choir at UCLA and collaborated on several projects with Hairston.
Parts of this collection may be restricted due to condition.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Jester Hairston (1901-2000) worked as composer, arranger, singer, conductor, and actor. He is known primarily as one of a small number of African American composers whose work transformed African-American spirituals into an accepted genre of choral music.

Hairston was born July 1, 1901 in Bellows Creek, North Carolina, near the plantation where his grandparents had been enslaved. Not long after his birth, the Hairston family moved to a steel mill town near Pittsburgh by the name of Homestead. Of this town, Hairston said, "There's nothing to do there but work in steel mills. That's the reason I got out of there as quickly as I could." Hairston attended University of Massachusetts in Amherst on a two year church scholarship, but was unable to continue for lack of money. He began working and met Northampton schoolteacher, Laura Anna Kidder. She was so impressed with his musical talent that she was willing to pay for his education with her savings. He subsequently repaid her for her loan. Hairston had applied to Tufts University, which was know for its music department, and was turned down. After his rejection, Hairston ran into a friend in New York, who was also African-American and who had been admitted to Tufts for his athletic skills. This student advised Hairston to write a letter to the music department and to "lay it on thick!" Hairston followed his advice and auditioned for Leo R. Lewis, the head of the music department on Lewis' front porch and was subsequently admitted. Hairston graduated from Tufts in 1929 and went on to study music theory at Julliard for two years.

After leaving Julliard, Hairston became the assistant director of the Hall Johnson Choir in New York and it was there that he developed his interest in African-American spirituals. For a short time he organized the African American 'The Jester Hairston Singers,' one of whose members was Margaret Isabel Swanigan who became his wife in 1939. In 1934/35 WPA hired him as assistant director of one of the largest music schools in New York City for African American children and adults. In 1935, the Hall Johnson Choir went to California to perform in the film, "Green Pastures." The next year Hairston made his break as a composer in Hollywood with the film "Lost Horizons" and also performed with Shirley Temple and her choir. The Hall Johnson choir also performed with Irvin Cobb on the Paducah plantation radio program for the Oldsmobile people for 26 weeks which was sponsored by GM and canceled eventually due to GM's prolonged difficulties with the famous sit down strikes in Michigan which invigorated the UAW. In 1937, the Hall Johnson choir gave a private concert for Stravinsky at Paramount studio after which Stravinsky planned to compose a group of choral works for the Hall Johnson Choir, mentioned in a contemporary letter by Hairston. Throughout the 1940s, he arranged choral music in over 40 films such as "Dual in the Sun," "Friendly Persuasion," and "Red River." He became one of Hollywood's most respected choral directors during this time period. When filmmakers stopped using large choral ensembles, Hairston performed as a character actor (often uncredited) in television and films, including "The Alamo," "Carmen Jones: "Tarzan," "To Kill a Mockingbird," "So This is Love," "Tanganyika" (an African movie), "Gypsy Colt," "Tarzan's Secret Jungle," St. Louis Blues and "In the Heat of the Night," "Lady Sings the Blues," "I'm Gonna Git You Sucka," "The Bingo Long Traveling All, Stars and Motor Kings," "Tender Killing Care," and "Being John Malkovich" . Hairston also portrayed Henry Van Porter and Leroy Smith in the controversial radio and television show "Amos 'n Andy." By 1951, he had also performed as Johnny in the Beulah Show and at Humphrey Bogart's new radio show, Bold Venture, as a Cuban singer. The US government sent him and an integrated choir on a good will tour to Asia in the 1950s.

Most importantly, Hairston was a prolific composer. He is most famous for "Amen," a spiritual so "authentic" many did not realize Hairston had composed it. The song was made famous through the film "Lilies of the Field;" Hairston performed the song, dubbing for lead actor, Sidney Poitier. In addition to composing film scores, Hairston composed or arranged more than 300 choral spirituals, including popular compositions such as "Elijah" and "Mary's Little Boy Child." Hairston, an expert in the history of African-American folk music and Negro spirituals, became one of the foremost interpreters, arrangers, and composers of this music, once stating ''I decided that I wanted to make my mark in folk songs because my grandparents were slaves […] I wanted to keep that music alive.''

Numerous music records include Jester Hairston as singer, composer, or conductor such as "Calypso Christmas" on Victor with the voices of Walter Shumann, "Christmas in the air" and "Great Getting' up mornin," "The Afro-American slave song: its African roots and American development" (Jester Hairston Metropolitan Choir), "A profile of Negro life in song," "Mary's boy child" (Venezuela), "Tarzan and the Mermaid" (Jester Hairston Choir) among many others.

Throughout the 1970s and 80s, Hairston was honored for his work across the US and he was frequently invited as guest conductor at high schools, colleges and church choirs. He also made several State Department sponsored goodwill tours to Africa, Asia, Europe and South America, once stating, "I will bring more love to China through American Negro folk songs than anything Kissinger can write." Throughout his lifetime, Hairston broke down many racial barriers in the United States. He was, for instance, the first African-American to be invited to conduct in the Mormon Tabernacle choir. Occasionally criticized for taking film and television roles that stereotyped African-Americans, Hairston said, "We had a hard time fighting for dignity. We had no power. We had to take it, and because we took it, the young people today have opportunities."

Late in his life, Hairston was active in organizing national reunions of the Hairston family, which traces its lineage to the Antebellum American South and sponsored reunions for both black and white descendents. The family, and Jester Hairston in particular, was the subject of Henry Wiencek's 1999 book ''The Hairstons: An American Family in Black and White.'' Wiencek wrote of Hairston, ''He never let go of his anger over slavery, but he also forgave. Still, he insisted that you should never forget your history.''

Hairston married Margaret Isabel Swanigan in 1939 and became stepfather to her daughter, Jeanne-Marie Swann. In recognition of his contributions to film and television, Hairston received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame located at 6201 Hollywood Blvd. Hairston died in Los Angles on January 18, 2000 and is interred at Inglewood Park Cemetery in California.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection contains some restricted material. Restrictions related to specific material are listed in the detailed contents list.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish. No documentation is available regarding the intellectual property rights in this collection.

did.unittitle: Sound recordings related to Jester Hairston

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains records that are related to or may be related to Hairston. It includes records of Hairston's work as a composer, a conductor, or choral director; recordings of other musicians performing Hairston's original compositions; and of concerts given in his honor. Records that were inscribed to Hairston and/or his wife Marge, are also located in this series. Records that may be related to Hairston include private recordings or unlabelled records that could be previously unrecorded songs or rehearsal sessions. Foreign language records are located at the end of the series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is subdivided into seven groups and arranged alphabetically within each: 1. 12-inch records that are related to Jester Hairston; 2. 12-inch titled and untitled records that may be related to Jester Hairston; and 3. 12-inch record jackets (without records) that are related to Jester Hairston 4. 10-inch records that are related to Jester Hairston; 5. 10-inch titled and untitled records that may be related to Jester Hairston; and 6. 10-inch record jackets (without records) that are related to Jester Hairston 7. 12-inch foreign language records related to Jester Hairston

did.unittitle: Foreign language records related to Jester Hairston (12")
Sound recordings unrelated to Jester Hairston

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains records owned by Jester Hairston, but not clearly related to him or his work. The records represent an array of musical genres from the 1910s through the 1980s.

Most of the records from before the 1940s are rare, 10-inch, 78rpm recordings produced by some of the first American record labels. Included is the original inventory number of the recording label or the Library of Congress call number (when available). While we removed the 10-inch records housed in bound record albums, we preserved the original albums and cross-referenced them (early 10-inch, 78rpm records were generally sold without jackets). Some albums Hairston labeled with genre categories.

Recordings dated after the 1950s are generally 12-inch shellac or vinyl records, which were relatively common and commercially available well into the 1990s. Foreign language records are located at the end of the series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is subdivided into four groups, and arranged alphabetically within each: 1. 12-inch records unrelated to Jester Hairston (roughly alphabetized) 2. 10-inch records unrelated to Jester Hairston 3. 12-inch foreign language records unrelated to Jester Hairston. 4. 10-inch foreign language records unrelated to Jester Hairston.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This date is approximate and refers to the range of years when this record album was likely manufactured. This record album was commercially produced as generic storage for 10-inch, 78rpm records, which were often sold without jackets. This album originally contained an assortment of records, which may or may not have been arranged by Jester Hairston.
This album originally contained the following records: MS040.002.035.00003 MS040.002.035.00004 MS040.002.035.00005 MS040.002.035.00006

did.unittitle: Foreign language records unrelated to Jester Hairston (12")
Foreign language records unrelated to Jester Hairston (10")
Jester Hairston subject files and musical scores

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains Hairston's personal file and a copy of his file from the Office of Estate and Gifts Planning microfiche collection (UA040), which contains biographical material, interviews, correspondence, clippings, press releases, speeches, and student records from the 1920s through the 1990s. This series also contains subject files and musical scores by other composers. These files include ASCAP (American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers) material, musical scores by Lorraine and Gale Enger, the score for a "Musical Introduction of Jester Hairston," material about Hairston's collaborator Salli Terri, and photographs of Hairston and Terri.

did.unittitle: ASCAP (American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers) material sent to Jester Hairston

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file includes clippings, press releases, speeches, and student records related to Jester Hairston.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These three sheets of handwritten music are located with the record 'Symphonic Spirituals,' where they were originally found. The song was written by Jester Hairston's cousin, Jackie Hairston.

did.unittitle: Musical scores by Lorraine and Gale Enger

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains musical scores (lyrics by Lorrain Enger and music by Gale Enger): "This I Know," "Something Happened," "Look Up," "Look at You," "There is a Way," "What is it About You," "Something Good's about to Happen," "Take a Look All Around," "The Good Things," "It's All So Very Diff'rent Now," "Our Love," "Just Once, and " I Can't Believe (Our Love is Through)."
